Expectation1: Ensure compliance with safety and regulatory standards
Situation1: An external inspector has raised immediate concerns that could halt operations unless issues are resolved
Situation2: They witness a serious wrongdoing, such as corruption or harm to others, and feel compelled to take decisive moral action.
Story:
As an engineer, I was reviewing the inspection report when the external inspector’s voice grew tense. “These irregularities can’t be ignored. If they aren’t fixed, I’ll have to shut this site down.” My mind raced—production would stop, people could lose their jobs, and the company’s reputation would suffer. My manager pulled me aside, his tone urgent. “We need this to go smoothly. Just sign off on the paperwork. We’ll fix the issues later.” 

But as a Hindu, I was taught to uphold dharma—righteousness above all. I had just witnessed a colleague slip the inspector an envelope, a bribe to overlook the safety lapses. My heart pounded. I knew what was expected of me as an engineer: keep the project running, protect my team’s livelihood. But my conscience screamed at the injustice, the harm that could come from ignoring these violations. I stood there, torn between my duty to my profession and my deeper duty to truth and ethics, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in on me.
